newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish Impexmetal wants to buy four firms. [CORRECTED 17:00 GMT]
newsitem.headline: Polish Impexmetal wants to buy four firms. [CORRECTED 17:00 GMT]

text.p: Polish metals trader Impexmetal SA wants to buy majority stakes in a copper processing firm, two ball-bearings producers and a zinc and lead mill, the company's sales director said on Wednesday.
"We are interested in investments in copper processor, ball-bearings producers and we also want to invest in zinc and lead mill," Krzysztof Walarowski said told a news conference.
He did not say when the company planned to finalise the acquisitions.

Walorowski said Impexmetal, which currently has 12 subsidiaries, was interested in buying stakes in Huta Metali Niezelaznych Szopienice, Hutmen SA, Fabryka Lozysk Tocznych Iskra SA and Fabryka Lozysk Tocznych Krasnik SA.
Walarowski said Impexmetal, which starts its initial public offering on Monday, would end negotiations with the issue underwriters on Thursday.

Impexmetal offers 2,657,643 new shares in large-investor tranche and 531,528 shares in an employee tranche while the state treasury is putting up for sale 2,976,560 existing Impexmetal shares it now owns.

Shares offered by the state treasury are priced at minimum 36 zlotys per share and shares offered by the firm are priced between 36 and 41 zlotys. (Corrects to show the different pricing structures of the share offers).
Walarowski added the management did not plan payouts for 1997 and 1998 as it wanted to earmark its earnings for the firm's own capital and investments, but did not elaborate.

The company's president Edward Wojtulewicz, also present, said the company was expecting its 1997 net profit to stay flat in real terms. Last year Impexmetal recorded a net profit of 20.7 million zlotys.
